thread.title: Fed up Arvada woman files federal lawsuit over wrong-number robo calls – The Denver Post
thread.title_full: Fed up Arvada woman files federal lawsuit over wrong-number robo calls – The Denver Post

author: Kirk Mitchell
title: Fed up Arvada woman files federal lawsuit over wrong-number robo calls – The Denver Post
text:
February 19, 2017 Bruce DeBoskey: Look at a nonprofit’s 990 tax form before donating your hard-earned money 
The automated calls to Newell’s cellular phone began May 2. The calls were to a Jeffrey Pike, someone Newell didn’t know. 
When enough was enough, Newell called the number, told Cobb’s “representative” that she was not Pike and no longer wished to receive any more robotic solicitations. 
But the calls from three phone numbers kept coming: at 2:45 p.m. on May 11; at 2:35 p.m. on May 13; at 1:54 p.m. on May 18; at 4:21 p.m. on May 20; at 1:28 p.m. on May 26; at 8:25 p.m. on May 27; at 1:34 p.m. on June 10; at 10:26 a.m. on June 17; at at 4:47 p.m. on June 21; at 10:11 a.m. on June 22; at 12:26 p.m. on June 27 and at 10:11 a.m. on June 29. 
Finally after nearly two months of robot calls, Newell picked up the phone herself and hired New Jersey lawyer David P. Force. Tags: Kirk Mitchell Kirk Mitchell is a general assignment reporter at The Denver Post who focuses on criminal justice stories. He began working at the newspaper in 1998, after writing for newspapers in Mesa, Ariz., and Twin Falls, Idaho, and The Associated Press in Salt Lake City. Mitchell first started writing the Cold Case blog in Fall 2007, in part because Colorado has more than 1,400 unsolved homicides.
